title: Add double-submit protection to the user signup form (Fixes #1734)
body:
### Functionality:
Adds double-submit protection to the user signup form

### Verification:
Sign out, sign up, try to click so fast that you get a 'name has already been taken' error.
(note: it won't happen)

**Note:** The form had previously used a link (as opposed to a submit button) to submit the form. I don't know why it was this way, or whether it matters. But, curiously, the link, when you hovered over it, was pointed to `/register/texterity`. The form, when submitted, did the correct sign-up action via JS despite this.

title: Clean up SponsorsController#badge_report code
body:
## Functionality

This is a refactoring to clean up the code in `SponsorsController#badge_report`, primarily to make the local variable names accurately describe the data assigned to them.

Those inaccurate names made it harder to get the high-priority fix for #1782 in place, and likely contributed to that bug being there in the first place.

## Performance

No change.

## Security

No change.

## Testing

Regression test all three filters (Earned, Rewardable, and All) on the sponsor badge reporter.

## Deployment

Simply deploy code.

title: Set correct content type based on uploaded image
body:
Functionality
---

When a web client uploads an image, it also sends what it believes to be the MIME type of the image. Some clients get it wrong, and send values such as `image/pjpeg`, `image/x-png`, or `application/octet-stream`.

We store the content type of the image both in our database and as metadata on the files we upload to Amazon S3. Once we have the file, we can examine it to determine its actual MIME type rather than relying on unreliable client information, and Paperclip actually does this to prevent some kinds of spoofing. Use the same method Paperclip does to determine what kind of image has been uploaded and set its content type accordingly.

I did not touch two attachments which appear to be unused: `image` on the Challenge model (there are no challenges with images set in prod), and `attachment` on the Content Entry model (there have been no new content entries since 2012). 

Performance
---

Processing images will be slightly slower as additional work is done.

Security
---

There should be no change in security related to this pull request. The `file` command is already being executed on the uploaded file, so running it a second time adds no new attack surface.

Testing
---

Upload a file using a client which sets the wrong content type, and verify that the entry in the database has the correct content type (and, in QA2, that the file has the correct Content-Type in S3).

One known bad client is Internet Explorer 7, which is available on Sauce Labs; you can test with this by logging in to https://qa.hubbubhealth.com/users/sign_in (since the main page is broken in IE7) and setting your avatar. Examine the value of `avatar_content_type` on the user record.

Another option is to set the iOS client to upload with a bad content type by [changing the content type](https://github.com/hubbubhealth/hubbub-ios/blob/c43ebb6dd71cbb8afc15c376c01824eb73e0bb43/Source/Shared%20Superclasses/VLCheckInEntryViewController.m#L289) and checking in a prove it photo. Examine the value of `proof_content_type` on the user challenge activity record.

Deployment
---

Simply deploy.

---

Issue #1767 set content type by examining image

title: Add New Tables and Models For Streamlined Device Accounts
body:
### Functionality

This pull request is to streamline the way we store tokens for our device
api accounts.  It's part of a larger block of code to streamline device
related logic, but I'm submitting this piece too keep the requests small.  

We are storing fitbit and nike tokens in the user table.  Moves, Jawbone, and
Withings tokens have their own individual tables.

This pull request adds a single place to store tokens.  I added 3 tables and related models and tests.

The `user_linked_accounts` table stores the user_id and the type of account (fitbit, jawbone, etc).
It also stores the manufacturer's account id.

Each `user_linked_account` entry has a related entry in either `oauth1_accounts` or `oauth2_accounts`
depending on the protocol the manufacturer uses.

The UserLinkedAccount model is using single table inheritance so that each entry in the 
`user_linked_accounts` table has it's own class like `UserLinkedAccount::Fitbit`.  This way we can 
add methods specific to each api.

This can ship as it is without affecting current functionality.  Before it goes live there will
be a data migration to add the existing tokens to the tables.

### Security

No change

### Performance

No change

### Testing

This adds no functionality, the site should function as normal.  All rspec tests should pass.

### Deploy

1. Deploy code
2. Run migration

title: Handle Non JSON reply from Moves API
body:
### Functionality

I was only expecting json responses from the api, but when the user's tokens are expired we can get an error like "expired_token".   So I changed the code to handle regular strings as well.

### Performance

No change

### Security

No change

### Testing

At the console

dummy = Devices::Moves::Client.new(1,2)
dummy.send(:response_error_message, "test") ## does not raise an error; returns "test"
dummy.send(:response_error_message, '{"error":"test"}') ## does not raise an error; returns "test"

### deploy

Deploy code

Close #1776

title: Set content-type by examining image
body:
When a web client uploads an image, it sends along the mime-type it believes the image to be. Currently we are using the information provided by the client verbatim by storing it in the database and setting the `Content-Type` on Amazon S3.

This turns out to be a problem with dumb clients, like Internet Explorer[[1]](http://stackoverflow.com/a/116059/25637)[[2]](http://struts.1045723.n5.nabble.com/uploaded-image-file-contentType-IE-vs-Firefox-td3477658.html). Various versions have uploaded files as `image/pjpeg` and `image/x-png` instead of their IANA-given designations of `image/jpeg` and `image/png`. Serving images with these content types works poorly when combined with clients who are strict in what they accept, such as the [AFNetworking library](https://github.com/AFNetworking/AFNetworking).

We should ignore the client's idea of the type of the file, examine the actual file, and set the content-type based on that examination.

---

Some data on what we have in production:

```psql
d9rjd3pkj5riqo=> select proof_content_type, count(*) from user_challenge_activities group by proof_content_type;
    proof_content_type    |  count
--------------------------+---------
                          | 2046874
 image/jpeg               |   20757
 image/png                |      42
 application/octet-stream |     442
 image/gif                |       1
(5 rows)

d9rjd3pkj5riqo=> select avatar_content_type, count(*) from users group by avatar_content_type;
 avatar_content_type | count
---------------------+-------
                     | 18595
 image/pjpeg         |  2264
 image/jpeg          |  5771
 image/x-png         |    91
 image/gif           |    95
 image/png           |   252
(6 rows)
```

title: explain "annual player limit" in rewards better
body:
somehow, somewhere make it more clear that:

annual means calendar year and the purpose of this limit is to help organizations that want to cap their employees' yearly rewards, most likely for tax purposes

this clarification has come up several time via Sales and Account Management over the years

title: Fix pagination on inbox
body:
Currently if you have multiple pages of messages and you delete all of the messages on one page individually, the pagination doesn't work correctly.

Solution: have the older messages slide up like any other app would (Gmail, etc). The page should always show the complete page of emails (10 unless there are less than 10 total).

title: 1731 pre cleanup
body:
In preparing to begin #1731, I was stymied by far-flung css selectors. This PR brings all css concerning the activity_widget into a single file. This is a continuation of the work that was begin in #1696. Essentially, this particular PR concerns only desktop styles that once lived in `scaffold.css`, but now live in `activity_widget.css.scss.erb.`

There should be no functional changes.

title: Player Registration allows submit button to be clicked multiple times and throws error
body:
Not sure if something has changed to make this happen more often but we have seen this error twice today.

I am able to recreate by:
https://qa.hubbubhealth.com/users/sign_up
filling out the form correctly with a new account
click on the continue button quickly two or more times

it will throw this error:
ActiveRecord::RecordNotUnique: ERROR: duplicate key value violates unique constraint "index_users_on_email"DETAIL: Key (email)=(kkkk@example.com) already exists.

title: v2 mobile activity stream
body:
implement a new activity stream for mobile/android

do no functional harm to existing activity stream

1st priority/iteration is to make it dynamically resize to fit the screen (width and height)

2nd priority/iteration is to remove older/newer buttons and fetch new activity stream entries on demand

wrap work in feature flag to allow for continual pushes to master

assigned to both @adamwong246 and @geraddavis 

this approach should also make for easier regression testing since this moves away from a shared web/mobile web activity stream

title: add helper text to connect/disconnect from company
body:
As a user, when you connect to your company, you are sharing all of your challenge participation in a non-identifiable aggregate format to your companys Dashboard and Hall of Records.

In addition, your company's hubbub administrators can see any specifics from challenges that are private to their employees only.
